Author: jansako#3330
Content: - If a send is made from a specific address in a specific wallet.dat file, there will be a new change address created IN THE SAME wallet.dat file, and only in that one wallet file. This tell me that someone must have actual access to THAT wallet file. Even if they would have just stole the wallet file previously,  the change address would have been created on the stolen wallet.dat file, and you would not have the private keys to it.

Author: jansako#3330
Content: ergo...

Author: jansako#3330
Content: unless code bug, of course, or the extremely unlikely case that the same change addy was created in the attacker's and the original wallet by pure blind luck

Author: ComputerGenie 👴🏼📢#7004
Content: I thought that too, but I dunno when/where I could/would have passed of any of my dat files 😕

Author: jansako#3330
Content: so what is left is physical access or a hack to your machine. I would say it is unlikely a hacker would hang around or use cli to send from the attacked machine, they would just grab the wallet.dat

Author: jansako#3330
Content: like I said, even giving someone your wallet.dat would not produce the result you are describing.
